sub_topic: Solving systems of linear equations using block matrices
message_1:
Solve the following system of linear equations using block matrices:

$$\begin{aligned} 3x_1 + 4x_3 &= 10 \\
x_2 + 2x_4 &= 5 \\
2x_1 + x_2 + 3x_3 + 4x_4 &= 20 \\
x_1 - 2x_2 + 2x_4 &= 0 \end{aligned}$$

Express the solution in the form of $\begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \\ x_4 \end{bmatrix}$.
message_2:
We can rewrite the given system of linear equations as a matrix equation:

$$\begin{bmatrix} 3 & 0 & 4 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 & 0 & 2 \\ 2 & 1 & 3 & 4 \\ 1 & -2 & 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \\ x_4 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 10 \\ 5 \\ 20 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$$

Now, let's partition the matrix into block matrices:

$$\begin{bmatrix} A_{11} & A_{12} \\ A_{21} & A_{22} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} X_1 \\ X_2 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} B_1 \\ B_2 \end{bmatrix}$$

Where:

$$A_{11} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix}, \ A_{12} = \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}, \ A_{21} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & -2 \end{bmatrix}, \ A_{22} = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 4 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$X_1 = \begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \end{bmatrix}, \ X_2 = \begin{bmatrix} x_3 \\ x_4 \end{bmatrix}, \ B_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 10 \\ 5 \end{bmatrix}, \ B_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 20 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix}$$

Now, we can solve the block matrix equation using the Schur complement method. First, we find the Schur complement $S$:

$$S = A_{22} - A_{21}A_{11}^{-1}A_{12}$$

$$S = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 4 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & -2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1/3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$S = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 4 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} 2/3 & 1 \\ 1/3 & -2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$S = \begin{bmatrix} 3 & 4 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} 8/3 & 2 \\ 4/3 & -4 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$S = \begin{bmatrix} 1/3 & 2 \\ -4/3 & 6 \end{bmatrix}$$

Now, we can solve for $X_2$:

$$X_2 = S^{-1}(B_2 - A_{21}A_{11}^{-1}B_1)$$

$$X_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1/3 & 2 \\ -4/3 & 6 \end{bmatrix}^{-1} \left( \begin{bmatrix} 20 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & -2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1/3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 10 \\ 5 \end{bmatrix} \right)$$

$$X_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1/3 & 2 \\ -4/3 & 6 \end{bmatrix}^{-1} \left( \begin{bmatrix} 20 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} 2/3 & 1 \\ 1/3 & -2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 10 \\ 5 \end{bmatrix} \right)$$

$$X_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1/3 & 2 \\ -4/3 & 6 \end{bmatrix}^{-1} \left( \begin{bmatrix} 20 \\ 0 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} 20/3 \\ -10 \end{bmatrix} \right)$$

$$X_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1/3 & 2 \\ -4/3 & 6 \end{bmatrix}^{-1} \begin{bmatrix} 40/3 \\ 10 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$X_2 = \frac{1}{18} \begin{bmatrix} 6 & -2 \\ 4/3 & 1/3 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 40/3 \\ 10 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$X_2 = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$$

Finally, we can solve for $X_1$:

$$X_1 = A_{11}^{-1}(B_1 - A_{12}X_2)$$

$$X_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1/3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \left( \begin{bmatrix} 10 \\ 5 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} 4 & 0 \\ 0 & 2 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix} \right)$$

$$X_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1/3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \left( \begin{bmatrix} 10 \\ 5 \end{bmatrix} - \begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ 4 \end{bmatrix} \right)$$

$$X_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 1/3 & 0 \\ 0 & 1 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} 6 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

$$X_1 = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \end{bmatrix}$$

Thus, the solution is:

$$\begin{bmatrix} x_1 \\ x_2 \\ x_3 \\ x_4 \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 2 \\ 1 \\ 1 \\ 2 \end{bmatrix}$$
